title: Model Comparison and Compression for PPE Detection
authors: Jayant Patel, Aravind Kumar, Dr. Sarah Mitchell
abstract: Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) detection is critical for industrial safety but often requires deploying heavy deep learning models on resource-constrained edge devices. In this study, we perform a comprehensive comparison of state-of-the-art object detection architectures and propose a novel compression pipeline. Our optimized YOLOv8n-based model achieves an 80.95% size reduction compared to the baseline while maintaining a mean Average Precision (mAP) within 1.5% of the original performance. This work demonstrates the feasibility of real-time, high-accuracy PPE compliance monitoring on low-power hardware.
methodology: Knowledge Distillation: Using a larger YOLOv8l teacher model to guide the training of a compact student network, recovering accuracy loss from architectural downsizing.
Channel Pruning: Identifying and removing redundant channels in the backbone network using L1-norm criteria, reducing computation by 40%.
Quantization Aware Training (QAT): Converting weights from FP32 to INT8 precision during fine-tuning to minimize quantization error on target hardware.
Data Augmentation: Employing Mosaic and MixUp augmentation strategies to improve model robustness against varying lighting conditions in industrial environments.
